questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 1:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the emotional shift from Jeremiah's fear to God's reassurance.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'before I formed you in the womb' (v.5) emphasizes divine foreknowledge
Pay attention to Jeremiah's response: 'I do not know how to speak' (v.6) and God's command: 'Do not be afraid' (v.8)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is called, WHAT God commands, WHERE this happens, and WHY God calls Jeremiah.
tips: Include that God calls Jeremiah while he is a youth (v.6)
Note the context: during the reign of Josiah (v.1) and the coming exile (v.10)
Highlight that God consecrates Jeremiah as a prophet to the nations (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's foreknowledge (v.5), Jeremiah's humility (v.7), or God's commissioning (v.10)?
tips: The phrase 'before I formed you in the womb' (v.5) is a profound statement of God's intimate knowledge and prior commitment
The contrast between Jeremiah's youth and God's command to 'pluck up and break down' (v.10) shows the call to a difficult mission
The almond tree and boiling pot (v.10) are symbolic of the coming disaster from the north (Assyrian invasion)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: God's call to Jeremiah is a message of divine sovereignty: He knows and consecrates us before we are born
This passage reassures Judah that God is with them in their exile and will use Jeremiah to bring judgment and restoration
The commissioning of Jeremiah as a prophet to the nations (v.10) indicates that God's plan for Judah extends beyond its borders

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of being called before birth, the role of the 'almond tree', or the dual message of destruction and building?
tips: The phrase 'before I formed you in the womb' (v.5) is a theological concept that God's plan for individuals is set from eternity
The almond tree (v.10) is a symbol of the coming disaster from the north (the Assyrian invasion) and is often interpreted as a sign of the time of judgment
The dual message of 'pluck up and break down' (v.10) and 'build and plant' (v.10) shows that God's actions will be both destructive and restorative

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Jeremiah's call to be a 'plucker up' and 'builder' in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you need to be 'plucked up' (removed) from sin or ungodly habits
Consider how God has consecrated you (like Jeremiah) for a specific purpose in your life
Pray for courage to 'go wherever I send you' (v.8) in a situation that requires faith

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His call to you and ask for courage to follow Him in your daily life.
tips: Thank God that He knew you before you were born and has consecrated you for a purpose
Pray for strength to be a 'plucker up' in a situation where others might not understand
Ask God to help you trust His word and not be afraid (as Jeremiah was told)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 2:1-25 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the LORD's past love and current unfaithfulness.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I remember' (v. 1-2) indicating God's enduring love
Pay attention to the image of the 'fountain of living waters' (v. 13) and 'broken cisterns' (v. 13)
The she-camel metaphor (v. 22) shows the unfaithfulness of Israel

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is unfaithful, WHAT they have done, WHERE this happened, and WHY they have turned away from the LORD.
tips: Include the role of the priests and rulers who have transgressed
Note the contrast between the past devotion (as a bride) and present unfaithfulness
Mention the specific action of 'hewing broken cisterns' (v. 13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the comparison of the LORD to the fountain of living waters (v. 13), the broken cisterns (v. 13), or the she-camel metaphor (v. 22)?
tips: The phrase 'fountain of living waters' (v. 13) is a powerful image of Christ in John 7:37-38
The broken cisterns (v. 13) illustrate how false religious practices are empty
The she-camel (v. 22) is a vivid picture of Israel's restlessness and unfaithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile about their unfaithfulness and the need to return to the LORD?
tips: Jeremiah is calling Judah to remember their past devotion as a bride to the LORD
The unfaithfulness has led to spiritual death (broken cisterns)
The call is for restoration through returning to the fountain of living waters

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'forsaken' (v. 13), the meaning of 'broken cisterns', or the role of the she-camel (v. 22)?
tips: 'Forsaken' here means abandoned by the LORD, but in this context, it's about Israel's rejection of the LORD as the living water
Broken cisterns: They are man-made and broken, so they cannot hold water (satisfy spiritual needs)
She-camel: A swift animal that runs around, symbolizing Israel's restlessness and unfaithfulness

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of the fountain of living waters (Christ) to your life this week? What broken cisterns might you need to abandon?
tips: Identify one false practice or idol that is not satisfying your spiritual needs
Pray to return to the LORD as the living water (Christ)
Commit to seeking the LORD in the same way Israel was called to return

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the fountain of living waters and ask for the strength to abandon broken cisterns.
tips: Thank God for Christ as the true fountain of living waters
Pray for the Holy Spirit to reveal broken cisterns in your life
Ask God to help you return to Him as the living water

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 3:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the emotional contrast between God's anger and mercy.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'faithless Israel' (v. 1, 3, 5, 12)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of God's anger and mercy in verses 11-15
Listen for the contrast between the land being polluted (v. 11) and the promise of restoration (v. 19)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Israel), WHAT God is doing (calling them to return), WHERE (Judah), and WHY (because they have been unfaithful).
tips: Include the threefold description of Israel's unfaithfulness: playing the whore (v. 11), the land being polluted (v. 11), and the failure to return (v. 12)
Note the role of Judah as the treacherous sister (v. 12)
Mention the promise of shepherds after God's heart (v. 15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the divorce metaphor (v. 1), the call to return (v. 12-13), or the promise of shepherds (v. 15-16)?
tips: The phrase 'I will give you shepherds after My own heart' (v. 15) is profound because it promises a new kind of leadership that is aligned with God's will
The contrast between the land being polluted (v. 11) and the restoration (v. 19) highlights the drastic need for repentance
The image of Jerusalem being called 'the throne of the LORD' (v. 17) signifies God's presence and authority

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah is calling Judah to repent and return to God, emphasizing that God's mercy is available despite their unfaithfulness
The passage reveals God's covenant faithfulness and His desire to restore His people, even after they have failed
This message foreshadows the New Covenant where Christ becomes the faithful shepherd (v. 15) and the true temple is the people of God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The metaphor of 'spiritual adultery', the concept of 'divorce', and the promise of 'shepherds after God's heart'?
tips: Spiritual adultery refers to Israel's idolatry and unfaithfulness to God, as they turned to other gods (v. 11)
The 'divorce' metaphor (v. 1) is a covenant termination by God, but it's not permanent because God calls for return
Shepherds after God's heart means leaders who are spiritually mature and guided by God's will, not human leaders

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the call to return (v. 12) apply to your life? What area of your life needs repentance and restoration?
tips: Identify one area where you have strayed from God (like spiritual adultery) and ask for forgiveness
Pray for the Spirit to give you shepherds (spiritual guidance) that will lead you to restoration
Commit to repentance in one specific area this week, just as Israel is called to return

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about God's call to return and His mercy
tips: Thank God for His patience and mercy despite our unfaithfulness
Ask for the courage to repent and return to Him
Pray for the Holy Spirit to guide you to become a 'shepherd' in your community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 4:1-18 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone of the prophet's anguish and the call to return.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'disaster' in verses 3, 5, 6
Pay attention to the phrase 'circumcise yourselves to the LORD' in verse 4
Listen for the cry of the trumpet in verse 5

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is called to return, WHAT they must do, WHERE this call is happening, and WHY Jeremiah gives this warning.
tips: Include the call for heart circumcision (v.4)
Note the warning of cities becoming ruins (v.7)
Mention the prophet's anguish (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the call for heart circumcision (v.4), the 'lion from the thicket' (v.6), or the prophet's anguish (v.10)?
tips: The phrase 'circumcise yourselves to the LORD' (v.4) is a powerful call to internal transformation
The 'lion from the thicket' (v.6) is a vivid image of a destroyer coming from the north (Babylon)
The repeated 'my anguish' (v.10) shows the prophet's deep emotional pain and concern

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile about their response to God's call?
tips: Jeremiah warns that without repentance, Judah will face total destruction (exile)
The call for heart circumcision (v.4) is the only path to avoid the disaster
This passage shows God's mercy in offering a chance to return before the disaster strikes

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The call for heart circumcision, the meaning of 'lion from the thicket', or the reversal of creation?
tips: Circumcision of the heart (v.4) is a spiritual concept, not physical; it means turning away from sin and toward God
The 'lion from the thicket' (v.6) is a metaphor for a military force (Babylon) that will destroy Judah
The description of the earth being 'without form and void' (v.10) refers to the desolation of Judah, not the creation story

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call for heart circumcision to your life this week?
tips: Identify one sin that you need to remove from your heart (like idolatry or unrighteousness)
Pray for God to help you 'circumcise your heart' by turning away from sin and toward Him
Ask for the courage to be part of the call to 'blow the trumpet' (v.5) for repentance

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of disaster from the north and the call for heart circumcision.
tips: Thank God for His warning and for the chance to turn away from sin
Ask for the strength to circumcise your heart and to avoid the disaster
Pray for the coming of the 'lion' (Babylon) to be stopped by repentance

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 5:1-22 aloud, focusing on the contrast between God's expectation and the people's actions.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'not one righteous' in verse 1
Pay attention to the phrase 'they have made their faces harder than rock' (verse 6)
Listen for the emotional tone of despair in verses 10-11

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (God) is searching for a righteous person, WHAT (a single individual who does justice and seeks truth), WHERE (Jerusalem), and WHY (to pardon the city).
tips: Include the description of the people's hardened hearts (verse 6)
Note the role of false prophets and corrupt leadership (verses 12-13)
Mention the consequence of God's judgment (verses 10-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'they have made their faces harder than rock' (verse 6), the false prophets and priests (verses 12-13), or the declaration of God's coming judgment (verses 10-11).
tips: The imagery of 'harder than rock' shows the complete unresponsiveness of the people
The false prophets and priests reveal the systemic corruption that has gone beyond individual sin
The phrase 'an appalling and horrible thing' (verse 14) emphasizes the severity of the situation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile regarding their unrighteousness and God's response?
tips: The entire nation has been hardened to truth
God's judgment is coming because there is no one righteous to be pardoned
This passage points to the need for Christ as the only righteous one

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The description of 'harder than rock' (verse 6), the meaning of 'the great' (verse 8), and the concept of God's vengeance on a nation with no righteous person (verses 10-11).
tips: 'Harder than rock' is a metaphor for unyielding hearts that refuse to change
'The great' refers to the powerful leaders of Judah who are responsible for the people's sin
God's judgment is not arbitrary but a response to the nation's complete rejection of truth

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: In light of the passage, what can you do this week to seek truth and righteousness in your life?
tips: Identify one area where your heart has become 'harder than rock' and pray for God's grace to soften it
Ask God to help you see the false prophets in your life and choose truth instead
Commit to a weekly practice of seeking God's truth in your decisions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for a heart that is open to God's truth and for the coming of Christ as the only righteous one.
tips: Thank God for the coming of Christ who is the only righteous one for whom God can pardon
Pray for the courage to repent when you feel hardened
Ask God to help you see the truth in your life and turn away from falsehood

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 6:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the urgency in 'Flee for safety' (v.1), the false peace (v.14), and the call to walk the ancient path (v.15).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'peace, peace' in v.14
The phrase 'uncircumcised ears' (v.10) indicates spiritual deafness
The call to 'walk in the ancient paths' (v.15) is a metaphor for following God's way

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being warned (the people of Judah), WHAT they are being told to do (flee, set up a signal, prepare for siege), WHERE (Jerusalem and the north), and WHY (their unfaithfulness and rejection of God's warnings).
tips: Include the false peace declaration (v.14)
Note the rejection of the ancient path (v.15-16)
The disaster comes from the north (v.1)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the false peace (v.14), the call to walk the ancient path (v.15), or the image of the siege (v.1-2).
tips: The phrase 'peace, peace' when there is no peace (v.14) is a powerful description of spiritual blindness
The ancient path (v.15) is a promise of rest that they have rejected
The image of 'glean thoroughly as a vine' (v.9) shows the complete destruction of the remnant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile that their rejection of God's warnings leads to destruction, but God still offers a path to rest through obedience (the ancient path).
tips: The warning is for the people who are unresponsive to God's word
The ancient path is the way of God's covenant, which was rejected by Judah
This passage points to the need for spiritual circumcision (hearing God's word)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The 'disaster from the north' (v.1), the 'uncircumcised ears' (v.10), and the 'false peace' (v.14).
tips: The north in this context refers to the enemy (Babylon) that would come against Judah
'Uncircumcised ears' means they are not receptive to God's word (spiritual condition)
The false peace is when they say 'peace' but there is no peace (spiritual blindness)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: In what situation do you need to reject false peace and walk the ancient path (the way of God) this week?
tips: Identify a time when you are saying 'peace' when there is no peace (e.g., in relationships, finances, or spiritual life)
Seek God's guidance to walk in the ancient path (v.15) by listening to His Word
Take one step this week to follow the path of rest that God offers

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His warning and the call to rest. Ask for the courage to reject false peace and walk in the ancient path.
tips: Thank God for the true peace that comes through Him
Pray for the ability to hear God's voice (circumcision of ears)
Ask for strength to walk in the ancient path and find rest

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 8:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of the LORD's warning and the repeated phrase 'peace, peace'.
tips: Notice the phrase 'they have healed the wound of My people lightly, saying: Peace, peace, when there is no peace' (v5)
Pay attention to the contrast between the stork (v3) and the people's ignorance of God's rules
The repeated word 'peace' in v5 shows the false assurance the people are giving

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the LORD is addressing, WHAT the LORD declares, WHERE this happens (in the context of Judah), and WHY the LORD is speaking (due to the people's persistent backsliding).
tips: Include the declaration of the bones being spread (v1)
Note the people's deceit and refusal to return (v1)
The LORD's attention without response (v2)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the false peace (v5), the stork's knowledge (v3), or the balm in Gilead (v5).
tips: The phrase 'Peace, peace, when there is no peace' (v5) is a powerful critique of the people's false assurances
The stork's appointed times (v3) contrasts with the people's lack of knowledge of God's rules
The question 'Is there no balm in Gilead? Is there no physician there?' (v5) points to the need for true healing

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: The main point is that Judah's persistent backsliding has led to the LORD's judgment (the bones being spread) and the need for true repentance
Jeremiah points to the coming exile and the ultimate hope in Christ (the balm of Gilead) as the true healer
This passage foreshadows the need for Christ to be the true physician and the balm for the spiritual wound of sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The metaphor of the bones being spread, the meaning of 'healed lightly', and the reference to the balm in Gilead.
tips: The phrase 'bones of the kings of Judah ... shall be brought out of their tombs' (v1) is a prophetic image of the final destruction of Jerusalem and the scattering of the people
'Healed lightly' (v5) means the people's false assurances were superficial and did not address the real spiritual wound
The balm in Gilead (v5) is a metaphor for Christ, the true healer, who provides complete restoration

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the theme of false peace in Jeremiah 8:5 apply to your life this week?
tips: When you feel the need to give false peace to someone (e.g., a friend or situation), ask: 'Is there real peace here?'
Reflect on a time when you thought you knew God's timing (like the stork) but you didn't, and pray for wisdom
Seek the true balm (Christ) for spiritual healing when you feel your wounds are not being addressed

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the need of true healing and the danger of false peace.
tips: Thank God for Christ as the true balm that heals the spiritual wound
Ask for the Holy Spirit to help you recognize false peace and to seek real healing
Pray for the people of Judah (or the church today) to turn away from deceit and back to God

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 9:1-10 aloud, focusing on the emotional lament and repeated phrases like 'adulterers', 'treacherous men', and 'deadly arrow'.
tips: Notice the contrast between Jeremiah's weeping and God's steadfast love
Pay attention to the repetition of 'I' in the lament (e.g., 'Oh that my head were waters')
Listen for the shift from despair to hope in the final verse (v.10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who is affected, what the problem is, where it occurs, and why it matters in one sentence.
tips: Include that Jeremiah is weeping over the slain of his people
Note the widespread deceit and broken trust among Judah
Mention God's warning of Jerusalem becoming a heap of ruins

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jeremiah's weeping (v.1), the deadly tongue (v.5), or the call to know God (v.10)?
tips: The image of 'eyes a fountain of tears' shows the depth of grief and helplessness
The phrase 'tongue is a deadly arrow' illustrates how lies can cause destruction
The final verse offers hope: true boasting is in knowing God, not in worldly things

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Judah has become spiritually bankrupt and untrustworthy
God will judge them for their deceit and idolatry
But God's faithfulness remains: He is the one who practices steadfast love, justice, and righteousness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The description of Judah as 'adulterers', the 'deadly arrow' metaphor, or God's promise of destruction?
tips: In ancient context, 'adulterers' refers to spiritual unfaithfulness (idolatry) and moral corruption
The 'deadly arrow' (v.5) is a metaphor for the destructive power of lies that can kill relationships and the community
God's judgment (v.8) is not a threat but a consequence of their sin, and it is part of His justice

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the warning about the 'deadly arrow' (tongue) this week?
tips: Identify one situation where your words might cause harm and choose kindness instead
Pray for the strength to speak truth without deceit in your relationships
Avoid boasting in your abilities but seek God's wisdom to avoid being a 'deadly arrow'

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's help in the context of this chapter: to guard your words and to know Him deeply.
tips: Thank God for His warning and for the truth that He is faithful
Ask for the courage to avoid deceitful speech and to be a witness of truth
Pray for the community to turn away from false trust and to seek God

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 10:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the LORD and idols in verses 5-6 and 10-11.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the LORD' (v.10, 11, 12) to emphasize His uniqueness
Pay attention to the description of idols as 'scarecrows in a cucumber field' (v.5) that cannot speak or move
Note the emotional tone: warning against idolatry but also a declaration of God's power and eternal nature

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the LORD is speaking to (Judah), WHAT He commands (to reject idolatry), WHERE this happens (in Judah before exile), and WHY (to avoid the vanity of idols and worship the true God).
tips: Include the description of idols as lifeless and powerless (v.5)
Note the contrast: idols cannot do good or evil (v.6) vs. the LORD as living and everlasting (v.10)
Describe the consequence of idolatry: the gods will perish (v.11)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 11:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'cursed be the man' (v.1), the olive tree metaphor (v.12), and the conspiracy against Jeremiah (v.19-20).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'cursed be the man who does not hear' (v.1) - it's a strong warning
Pay attention to the olive tree metaphor in verse 12: 'The LORD once called you a green olive tree, beautiful with good fruit'
The emotional tone shifts from warning to urgent call for obedience (v.1-2) to the plot against Jeremiah (v.19-20)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the LORD and the people of Judah) is involved, WHAT (the broken covenant), WHERE (the cities of Judah), and WHY (disobedience to God's commands).
tips: Include the warning about the curse for not hearing the covenant (v.1)
Note the olive tree metaphor (v.12) as a symbol of Judah's past fruitfulness
Mention the conspiracy among the men of Judah to kill Jeremiah (v.19-20)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the covenant warning (v.1-2), the olive tree metaphor (v.12), or the conspiracy against Jeremiah (v.19-20)?
tips: The olive tree metaphor (v.12) - Judah was called a green olive tree (meaning fruitful) but now they are unfruitful due to sin
The conspiracy to kill Jeremiah (v.19-20) - shows the severe consequences of breaking the covenant
The curse on those who don't hear the covenant (v.1) - a direct call to obedience that is repeated

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Judah's broken covenant leads to divine judgment and exile
The LORD's covenant is absolute and requires obedience, but the people have chosen disobedience
This passage foreshadows the exile and the need for repentance

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The covenant of the fathers, why Judah is cursed, the conspiracy against Jeremiah?
tips: The phrase 'cursed be the man' (v.1) - in ancient context, curses were often part of the law (Deuteronomy) but here it's a warning for the present
The olive tree metaphor (v.12) - Judah was called a green olive tree (meaning fruitful) but now they are unfruitful due to sin
The conspiracy against Jeremiah (v.19) - why would they want to kill a prophet? Because he was calling them to obey the covenant

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the theme of broken covenant and the need for obedience apply to your life this week?
tips: Consider an area where you have been disobedient to God's commands (like the covenant in this passage)
Pray for the strength to obey God's commands even when it's hard
Ask God to help you see the cost of disobedience and the blessing of obedience

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His covenant and ask for help to stay faithful.
tips: Thank God for the covenant that He established with His people
Pray for courage to obey God's commands even when it's hard
Ask the Holy Spirit to help you avoid the conspiracy of disobedience

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 12:1-16 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone and repeated phrases like 'Why' in the opening verses and 'My heritage has become to Me like a lion in the forest'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Why' in verses 1-3 showing Jeremiah's frustration
Pay attention to the contrast between God's nearness and the heart's distance in verses 6-7

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is lamenting, WHAT they are complaining about, WHERE this occurs (in Judah), and WHY (the wicked prospering and land desolation).
tips: Include Jeremiah's complaint about the wicked thriving (verses 1-3)
Note the land's desolation and effect on animals (verses 4-5)
Mention the abandonment of his home and heritage (verses 11-12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast between God's nearness and the heart's distance (verses 6-7), the image of heritage becoming a lion (verse 12), or the promise of restoration (verses 13-16)?

Pay attention to the phrase 'act, O LORD, for Your name's sake' (v.7)
Listen for the contrast between the people's cries and the false prophets' promises (v.19)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Judah) is suffering, WHAT (drought and famine), WHERE (Jerusalem and Judah), and WHY (their iniquity and false prophets).
tips: Include the image of the doe forsaking her fawn (v.5)
Note that the people send for water but find none (v.1, v.19)
Mention the false prophets' false promise of no famine or sword (v.19)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the plea for God's intervention (v.7), the image of the doe (v.5), or the false prophets' lies (v.19)?
tips: The image of the doe forsaking her fawn (v.5) is a powerful symbol of the severity of the drought and the impact on even the most vulnerable.
The phrase 'act, O LORD, for Your name's sake' (v.7) shows the people's desperate need for God's action.
The false prophets' claim that 'you shall not see the sword, nor shall you have famine' (v.19) is a stark contrast to the reality of the drought.

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile about the consequences of their iniquity and the need for genuine repentance?
tips: Jeremiah warns that Judah's false hope (through false prophets) will lead to divine judgment.
The true hope of Israel is Christ, who is the Savior in time of trouble (as per the Christ Connection).
God does not accept their prayers and offerings because they are not in right relationship with Him.

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'they have loved to wander' (v.12), why God refuses their prayers (v.11), and the false prophets' message (v.19)?
tips: In Hebrew, 'loved to wander' (v.12) means they have been rebellious and have not stayed in the covenant.
God's refusal of their prayers and burnt offerings (v.11) is because they are in a state of spiritual death and not repentant.
The false prophets' promise of no famine or sword (v.19) is a deception that leads to their destruction.

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of drought and famine (the spiritual dryness) in your life this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are experiencing spiritual dryness (e.g., lack of motivation, emotional emptiness).
Pray for God to act for His name's sake (v.7) when you feel desperate.
Avoid the false hope of easy solutions (like the false prophets) and instead seek God's truth.

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the drought and famine in your life, and the need for Christ as the true hope.
tips: Thank God for His provision in Christ, who is the true hope (v.19).
Ask for the strength to trust God in the midst of drought and famine (spiritual dryness).
Pray for the people of Judah (and us) to turn from false hope and seek the true God.

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 15:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of God's declaration and the repeated phrases of judgment.
tips: Notice the phrase 'My heart would not turn' (v.1) shows God's firm resolve
Pay attention to the repetition of 'to' in 'to pestilence, to the sword, to famine, to captivity' (v.2)
The phrase 'I am weary of relenting' (v.10) conveys deep exhaustion

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (God and Jeremiah) does WHAT (declares judgment) WHERE (on Judah) and WHY (because of their rejection).
tips: God's declaration: 'Though Moses and Samuel stood before Me, yet My heart would not turn' (v.1)
The judgment: 'Those who are for pestilence, to pestilence...' (v.2)
Jeremiah's suffering: 'I have bereaved them; I have destroyed My people' (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's declaration of irreversible judgment (v.1-2), Jeremiah's lament (v.5-6), or the joy in God's Word (v.19).
tips: The phrase 'I have bereaved them; I have destroyed My people' (v.10) shows the depth of God's sorrow
The contrast between judgment and the joy in God's Word: 'Your words were found, and I ate them...' (v.19)
The personal cry: 'Woe is me, my mother, that you bore me, a man of strife!' (v.5)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: God's judgment on Judah is irreversible because of their persistent rejection (v.1-2)
Jeremiah's suffering is a result of God's righteous judgment, not a sign of weakness
The ultimate hope is found in God's Word, which brings joy and life (v.19)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'My heart would not turn' (v.1), the meaning of 'four kinds of destroyers' (v.2), or the contrast between judgment and joy (v.19).
tips: 'My heart would not turn' (v.1) refers to God's refusal to relent despite intercession, emphasizing the severity of sin
The 'four kinds of destroyers' (v.2) are: sword, dogs, birds, and beasts - representing the total destruction of Judah
The phrase 'I have bereaved them' (v.10) means God has made them sorrowful and broken, not just the physical destruction

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's Word being a source of joy and delight in your life this week?
tips: Read Jeremiah 15:19 and ask: What part of God's Word has brought me joy this week?
When faced with difficult circumstances, remember that God's Word is the source of joy (like Jeremiah's experience)
Spend time in prayer and Scripture to let God's Word become your delight

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's judgment on Judah and the hope found in His Word. Ask for strength to trust His promises.
tips: Thank God for the unchanging character that even in judgment brings hope
Pray for the people of Judah to hear and respond to God's Word
Ask God to help you find joy in His Word despite life's difficulties

tips: Notice the phrase 'you shall not take a wife, nor shall you have sons or daughters' in verse 1 (emphasizing total separation)
Pay attention to the repetition of 'the voice of mirth and the voice of gladness' in verses 15-16 (a stark contrast to the coming death)

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include the warning about no wives or children (v.1-2)
Note the prohibition on mourning and feasting (v.4-5)
Mention the cause: Judah's sin of forsaking the LORD (v.14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the command to have no children (v.1), the silence of joy (v.15-16), or the warning about the fathers' iniquity (v.14).
tips: The phrase 'you shall not go into the house of mourning' (v.5) is emotionally stark and shows the complete severance from community
The contrast between 'the voice of mirth and the voice of gladness' being silenced (v.15-16) highlights the total destruction of joy in Judah
The explanation that the cause is the fathers' sin (v.14) connects the present generation to past unfaithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah is showing that the coming exile is a direct result of Judah's idolatry and the unfaithfulness of their ancestors
The passage emphasizes that God's judgment is not arbitrary but a consequence of repeated rebellion
This passage foreshadows Christ's mission: being without a home and family (as a sign) to bring salvation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command to have no children, the silence of joy, or the explanation of the cause (fathers' sin).
tips: The phrase 'you shall not have sons or daughters in this place' (v.1) refers to the immediate generation in Jerusalem, not a permanent ban
The term 'fishers' in v.17 is a metaphor for those who will gather the people of Judah (like the disciples of Christ)
The phrase 'the voice of mirth and the voice of gladness' being silenced (v.15-16) is a sign of God's judgment, not a temporary sadness

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Jeremiah's life of sacrifice (no wife, no children) foreshadows Christ's mission. What area of your life requires you to be a 'fisher of men' this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you are called to bring others to Christ, like Jeremiah was called to prophesy
Think about how you can share the gospel with someone in your community this week
Practice being a 'fisher' by reaching out to one person who may be lost

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about Jeremiah's warning: that the joy of life is silenced because of sin. Ask God to help you live without sin and to be a fisher of men.
tips: Thank God for the truth that our sins lead to destruction
Pray for courage to be like Jeremiah in a time of judgment
Ask God to send fishers (disciples) to your life this week

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 17:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the cursed and blessed.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the heart' (vv. 1-3, 9)
Pay attention to the contrast: 'shrub in the desert' (v. 5) vs. 'tree by water' (v. 6)
The phrase 'the heart is deceitful above all things' (v. 9) is the central declaration

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the LORD is describing, WHAT the heart does, WHERE this occurs (in the context of Judah), and WHY Jeremiah is writing this.
tips: Include the LORD's judgment on Judah's heart (vv. 1-3)
Note the contrast between the cursed man (v. 5-6) and the blessed man (v. 7-8)
Describe the LORD's search of the heart (vv. 9-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the heart's deceitfulness (v. 9), the cursed man (v. 5-6), or the tree by water (v. 6)?
tips: The phrase 'the heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately sick' (v. 9) is a profound description of human nature that resonates deeply.
The contrast between the cursed man (like a shrub in the desert) and the blessed man (like a tree by water) in v. 5-8 is powerful and memorable.
The LORD's declaration that He searches the heart and tests the mind (v. 9-10) shows His intimate knowledge and authority.

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah's purpose was to warn Judah that their trust in human strength and unrepentant heart would lead to exile and judgment.
He emphasizes that only by trusting the LORD (the only true source of life) can one avoid being like the shrub in the desert.
This passage is a call to repentance and a reminder of God's sovereignty over the heart.

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The description of the heart's deceitfulness, the contrast between the cursed and blessed, or the concept of the LORD searching the heart?
tips: The phrase 'the heart is deceitful above all things' (v. 9) is a strong statement that may seem shocking because it's so absolute; it emphasizes that human hearts are fundamentally corrupt.
The term 'Asherim' (v. 1-3) refers to the Canaanite fertility idols that were common in Judah, so the passage is criticizing idolatry and false worship.
The concept of the LORD 'searching the heart' (v. 9-1:10) is a divine attribute that shows God's intimate knowledge of our innermost thoughts.

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of the heart being deceitful and the need for trust in the LORD to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where your heart is deceitful (e.g., pride, false trust in others) and pray for the LORD to search it (v. 10).
Practice trusting the LORD in a small way, like when you face a situation where you feel unprepared (like the tree by water that doesn't fear heat).
Ask the LORD to heal your 'desperately sick' heart (v. 10) by removing the deceit and bringing you to a place of trust.

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for searching your heart and healing it. Ask for courage to trust Him when your heart is deceitful.
tips: Thank God for searching your heart and knowing your thoughts (v. 9-10).
Pray for courage to trust the LORD when your heart is deceitful and you feel like a shrub in the desert.
Ask God to heal your heart and make you like the tree by water that remains green in the heat.

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 19:1-13 aloud, focusing on the phrases: 'the Valley of the Son of Hinnom', 'the ears of everyone who hears of it will tingle', and 'so will I break this people and this city'.
tips: Note the repetition of 'this place' (three times) to emphasize the judgment
Pay attention to the contrast between the people's actions (forsaken, profaned, filled with blood) and God's response (breaking)
The phrase 'as one breaks a potter's vessel' is a key metaphor for irreparable destruction

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the people of Judah and the elders), WHAT (God's judgment on Jerusalem), WHERE (the Valley of Hinnom), WHY (they have forsaken God and committed child sacrifice), and HOW (by breaking the potter's flask).
tips: Include the three-day journey to the Valley of Hinnom as described in the passage
Note that the people have filled the place with the blood of innocents and built high places of Baal
The breaking of the flask symbolizes the finality of the destruction

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the imagery of the broken flask (v.13), the valley of Hinnom (v.1), or the people's sin (v.1-5).
tips: The phrase 'so will I break this people and this city' (v.13) is a strong declaration of God's judgment
The valley of Hinnom was a place of child sacrifice in ancient Israel, so the context is deeply tragic
The potter's flask is a symbol of something that can be repaired, but here it is broken forever

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah warns Judah that their unfaithfulness (child sacrifice and idolatry) will lead to destruction
The broken flask symbolizes that the city and nation will be destroyed beyond repair, so they must repent before it's too late
This passage points to future redemption through Christ as the only hope

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reference to child sacrifice in Judah? Why is the valley of Hinnom significant? What does 'irreparable breaking' mean?
tips: Child sacrifice was forbidden by God in Israel (Leviticus 18:21, 20:27), yet Judah engaged in this practice
The Valley of Hinnom was historically associated with child sacrifice in ancient Israel
The phrase 'irreparable breaking' (v.13) means destruction that cannot be undone or repaired

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of irreparable consequences for unrepentant sin. What area of your life needs to be broken (like the flask) to allow God's restoration?
tips: Consider an area where your sin has led to broken relationships or spiritual disconnection
Ask God to break the pattern of your sin so that He can restore you
Like the flask, focus on one area that needs to be 'broken' (i.e., abandoned) to be renewed

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment that exposes sin. Ask for the people of Judah to repent and for the city to be saved through Christ.
tips: Thank God for His judgment that exposes sin
Pray for the people of Judah to repent and for the city to be saved through Christ
Ask God to break your sin patterns and restore you

Pay attention to the internal conflict described in 'burning fire shut up in my bones' (v.9)
Emphasize the raw expression of despair: 'Cursed be the day on which I was born!' (v.10)

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include Pashhur (the priest) beating Jeremiah and putting him in the stocks (v.1-3)
Note Jeremiah's declaration that the LORD calls Pashhur 'Terror on Every Side' (v.4-5)
Describe Jeremiah's internal anguish: the fire in his bones and the curse on his birth (v.8-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jeremiah's declaration of terror (v.5), the fire in his bones (v.9), or his curse on birth (v.10)?
tips: The phrase 'Terror on Every Side' (v.5) is a powerful metaphor for the coming destruction of Judah
The description of 'burning fire shut up in my bones' (v.9) shows the intense spiritual pain of being a prophet
The curse: 'Cursed be the day on which I was born!' (v.10) is a raw expression of despair that highlights the cost of prophesying

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah warns that Judah will be destroyed by Babylon (v.5) and that the current leadership (Pashhur) will be destroyed by their own actions
The passage emphasizes the personal cost of being a prophet of God's judgment
This serves as a warning that even the most faithful will face severe consequences if they do not turn from sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'terror on every side', the fire in bones, or the curse on birth?
tips: 'Terror on every side' (v.5) is a Hebrew term that describes a state of being surrounded by danger, not a physical terror but a spiritual one
The 'fire in bones' (v.9) is a metaphor for the intense spiritual pain of God's message being rejected
The curse on birth (v.10) is a rare biblical expression of despair, showing the depth of Jeremiah's anguish

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Jeremiah's anguish to your life? Consider a situation where you feel God's message is being rejected and you are experiencing internal conflict.
tips: When you feel your faith is being tested, take time to pray and let God's word be a fire within you (like Jeremiah's experience)
Ask God to give you the strength to endure when your message is rejected, just as Jeremiah endured
Practice being still and letting the fire of God's word burn within you, even when it feels like it's being held in

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the fire of His word that burns within you and ask for strength to endure when your message is rejected.
tips: Thank God for the fire of His word that burns within you (v.9)
Pray for courage to be a voice of God in a time of rejection
Ask God to give you the strength to endure the internal conflict that comes with being a faithful witness

questions.title: Read Aloud

tips: Notice the phrase 'Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel' (v. 8)
Pay attention to the contrast in verses 9: 'way of life' vs. 'way of death'
Listen for the emotional tone of urgency and finality in the declaration

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the LORD speaks to, WHAT the LORD commands, WHERE it takes place, and WHY (the context of the message).
tips: Include King Zedekiah and his envoys (Pashhur and Zephaniah) who sent the inquiry
Note the command: God will destroy Jerusalem and its inhabitants, but those who surrender to the Chaldeans will live
The context: Judah is under threat from Nebuchadnezzar (Babylon) and has been asking for God's help

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's declaration of turning back weapons (v. 8), the way of life vs. death (v. 9), or the ultimatum for survival (v. 9).
tips: The phrase 'I will turn back the weapons of war' (v. 8) shows God's decisive action against Judah's rebellion
The stark choice in v. 9: 'he who stays in this city shall die by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence' vs. 'he who goes out and surrenders to the Chaldeans shall live'
This ultimatum is particularly resonant because it offers hope in the face of inevitable destruction

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah is warning Judah that they have no hope in God's intervention but must choose between destruction and surrender to the Babylonian conquerors
The theological significance: God's justice in punishing unfaithfulness, but also His provision of a way to survive through submission to the enemy's authority
This passage emphasizes that God's will is absolute and the choice is between life (surrender) and death (resistance)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The destruction of Jerusalem, the role of the Chaldeans, and the 'way of life vs. death' concept.
tips: In the ancient Near East, child sacrifice was common in Canaan but God rejects it (this passage is not about child sacrifice)
The term 'Chaldeans' refers to the Babylonian empire, which was the enemy of Judah at this time
The phrase 'way of life and way of death' is a common biblical motif, but here it's applied to the immediate crisis of the city and the choice of survival

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can this passage be applied to your life today?
tips: This week, when facing a crisis (e.g., financial, relational, health), consider the choice: 'Do I stay and face destruction (the way of death) or surrender to God's will (the way of life) to find surv
Ask God for the courage to choose surrender in the face of uncertainty, just as the passage urges the people of Jerusalem to go out and surrender to the Chaldeans
Surrender here means stepping out in faith, not giving up but trusting God's plan for your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of surrender and the choice between life and death.
tips: Thank God for the clear warning when we are in danger and for the choice He gives us
Pray for the courage to choose the way of life (surrender to God's will) rather than the way of death (resistance)
Ask God to help us see the enemy (Babylon) as a metaphor for the forces of sin and death that we must surrender to His authority

questions.title: Best Bit

The term 'desolation' (v. 5) refers to the city being abandoned and the temple destroyed in the exile

questions.title: Application

Think about how you can do justice without being a king (e.g., through small acts of kindness)

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God for the promise that Christ fulfills the Davidic throne through the virgin birth
Pray for the strength to be just to the vulnerable and to see the need for justice in society

questions.title: Main Point

This vision shows God's faithfulness despite the exile

Zedekiah was the last king of Judah who was captured by Babylon and held in the city of Jerusalem (so he and his officials are the ones left behind)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of God's restoration and a new heart to know Him in your life this week?

questions.title: Prayer

Ask God to help you trust His promise when things seem bad

questions.title: Read Aloud

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include the 23 years of prophetic warnings (Jeremiah 25:1)

Mention the judgment on Babylon after the 70 years (Jeremiah 25:8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the 70 years (v. 7), the cup of wrath (v. 11), or God's promise to judge Babylon (v. 8).
tips: The cup of wrath (v. 11) is a powerful image of God's judgment that will be poured out on the nations
The 70 years (v. 7) is a specific, measurable time that shows God's precision in His judgments
God's promise to judge Babylon (v. 8) is a sign of His sovereignty over even the nations that oppress Judah

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: God's warning to Judah for their unrepentant sin leads to 70 years of captivity in Babylon

The cup of wrath is a sign of God's judgment on the nations that refuse to turn from sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 70-year period, the cup of wrath, and why God punishes Babylon after the 70 years?

The cup of wrath is a metaphor for God's judgment that will be poured out on the nations (not a physical cup but a spiritual reality)
God punishes Babylon after the 70 years because they were the instrument of Judah's destruction and their iniquity will be judged (v. 8)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the concept of God's 70-year timing to your life this week? Consider a situation where God's timing is crucial.

Pray for courage to trust God's timing in your current situation (e.g., a season of discipline or waiting)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty in the 70 years of judgment and restoration. Ask for wisdom to endure the cup of wrath without being overcome.
tips: Thank God for His promise that after 70 years, He will restore Judah (as in the context of the chapter)
Pray for courage to face the cup of wrath (the challenges in life) without turning away from Him
Ask God to judge your heart so you don't become like Babylon (the oppressor) but instead become a nation that serves Him

Pay attention to the emotional tension in the phrase 'You shall die!' (verse 14)
The officials' defense in verses 16-17 shows the community's role in protecting truth-tellers

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include the three-day journey to the court of the LORD's house (verse 1)
Note the warning: the temple will be destroyed like Shiloh (verse 18)
The reason: the people's refusal to obey God's law (verse 13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning about Shiloh (verse 18), the officials' defense (verses 16-17), or the story of Uriah (verses 19-20).
tips: The repetition of 'Shiloh' as a symbol of destruction resonates because it's a historical place that was destroyed by the Philistines
The officials' defense shows the community's responsibility to protect truth-tellers even when they are threatened
Uriah's story highlights the cost of speaking truth: fleeing to Egypt and then being killed by the king

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah warns that if Judah does not obey God's law, the temple will be destroyed (like Shiloh) and they will face exile

This passage is a call to repentance and a warning of the consequences of unbelief

questions.title: Difficulties

The story of Uriah (verses 19-20) shows how the king (Jehoiakim) would kill prophets who spoke truth, even if they fled to Egypt

questions.title: Application

Reflect on what it means to 'stand in the court of the LORD's house' (verse 1) and how you can be a witness of truth in your daily life

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God that He provides the strength to speak truth even when it's dangerous
Ask for the courage to be like Jeremiah and to stand up for truth in your community
Pray that the church (like the officials) will protect truth-tellers and not let them be silenced

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include key elements: the yoke (v.2), God's sovereignty (v.3), and false prophets' opposition (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the yoke on the neck (v.2), God's declaration of sovereignty (v.3), the false prophets' lie (v.10), or the consequence of disobedience (v.11)?

God's declaration of sovereignty (v.3) shows He is the ultimate creator and ruler
The false prophets' lie (v.10) directly challenges the people's faith

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah's purpose was to call Judah to submit to Babylon (the new reality) and avoid destruction
This passage shows God's sovereignty extends to nations and submission to His appointed rulers is part of His covenant plan

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: Babylon as God's servant: God used Babylon (a pagan empire) to correct Judah, not because Babylon was holy
God commands submission: This is about His sovereign plan to bring Judah to humility and renewal through exile
False prophets: They claimed the land would be safe without Babylon (v.10)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'yoke on the neck' from this passage. What area of your life requires you to submit to God's will this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you're resisting God's will (e.g., relationships, decisions)

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God for His sovereignty and the truth that He has a plan

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include that Hananiah broke the wooden yoke bars from Jeremiah's neck (v. 10)
Note that Hananiah died that year (v. 20)
Mention that Jeremiah prophesied the consequences of false prophecy (v. 14-15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Hananiah breaking the wooden yoke (v. 10), the phrase 'wooden bars' vs 'bars of iron' (v. 11), or Hananiah's death (v. 20).
tips: The physical act of breaking the wooden yoke symbolizes the false promise (wooden = temporary, weak)
The shift to 'bars of iron' (v. 11) shows the reality of Babylon's power and the false prophecy's end
Hananiah's death in the same year (v. 20) is a direct consequence of his false prophecy

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile about the difference between true and false prophets?
tips: Jeremiah warns that false prophets (like Hananiah) will be punished by God (death)
True prophets speak God's hard truth (as in Jeremiah's warning of exile) and not what people want to hear
This passage shows that God's true prophets are tested by the people's response

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The false prophecy of peace, the meaning of the yoke, or Hananiah's death?
tips: In ancient Near East, 'yoke' symbolized the burden of war or oppression (Babylon's rule) - wooden yoke (weak) vs. iron yoke (strong, Babylonian power)

The phrase 'you have broken wooden bars, but you have made in their place bars of iron' (v. 11) shows that Hananiah's prophecy of peace was false because it was a temporary solution (wooden) that woul
Why did Hananiah die that year? Because he was a false prophet who spoke the word that would not come to pass (as Jeremiah warned)

questions.title: Application

Pray for courage to be a true prophet in your daily life

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God for the false prophets who have been punished (like Hananiah) and for His true prophets who speak truth
Pray for courage to speak truth when it's hard (like Jeremiah)
Ask God to help you recognize and avoid false prophets in your life

Restoration from captivity refers to both physical exile and spiritual bondage

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include the context of Judah's exile and the weeping of Rachel (v.1-10)
Note the promise of God's law being written on hearts (v.33)
Mention the restoration of the people from the wilderness (v.1-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the weeping of Rachel (v.1-10), the promise of the new covenant (v.31-34), or the phrase 'I will remember their sin no more' (v.34)?

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?

This covenant is a sign of God's mercy and the beginning of a new era for Israel

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'new covenant', the phrase 'I will write it on their hearts', or the idea that God 'remembers' sin no more?
tips: The 'new covenant' is distinct from the old covenant of law (Exodus 24:3-8) and is a covenant of grace through Christ

God 'remembering sin no more' does not mean sin is erased but that God's wrath is removed and forgiveness is granted

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of God writing His law on your heart this week?

Reflect on the weeping of Rachel and how God's love continues for you despite your failures

tips: Thank God that He writes His law on your heart and forgives your sins
Pray for the courage to live by the new covenant and not be bound by old sins
Ask God to help you remember His promises of forgiveness and restoration

This passage foreshadows the New Covenant where Christ purchases His people from sin

questions.title: Difficulties

questions.title: Application

Think about how you can take a step of faith in a small, tangible way like Jeremiah did
Pray for God to give you the courage to trust His promises even when the situation seems hopeless

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God that He is the God of all flesh and nothing is too hard for Him
Pray for the courage to trust God's promises in the midst of current struggles
Ask God to give you the heart to buy a field of hope in your life

The phrase 'many similar words were added to them' (v. 23) emphasizes that God's word continues even when rejected

The context of the king burning the scroll is a political move to suppress God's message, which was common in the time of Jeremiah
The phrase 'many similar words were added to them' (v. 23) indicates that God's word is cumulative and continues to be written in response to the rejection

questions.title: Application

Jeremiah's protection highlights God's faithfulness to His prophets even in the midst of judgment

'Blinded' (v.11) is a literal and symbolic act: it represents the loss of sight in the spiritual sense, as in Isaiah 29:18

questions.title: Application

Pray for courage to trust God in difficult circumstances, just as Jeremiah did
Spend time in prayer this week to seek God's protection for your life

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God that He preserved Jeremiah despite the fall of Jerusalem

He points to God's provision for the remnant through Gedaliah
This passage shows that even in exile, God provides a place for the remnant to stay

tips: Nebuzaradan released Jeremiah because the exile was complete and he was no longer a captive of the city (Jerusalem was destroyed)
Gedaliah was appointed by Babylon to govern the remaining cities of Judah, but he was not a king and his authority was limited
Jeremiah chose to stay in Judah because he saw the remnant (the people left in the land) as God's people, not the exiles in Babylon

tips: Include the specific leaders: Johanan and the commanders of the forces
Note the remnant of Judah that came with them
The reason: they were fleeing from the Chaldeans (Babylon) and the accusation that Jeremiah was set against them

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the people's decision to flee to Egypt (v.10), Jeremiah's warning about the stones (v.11), or the specific location Tahpanhes (v.11)?
tips: The people's choice to flee to Egypt despite God's warning shows their rejection of His word
The stones hidden at Pharaoh's palace will be a sign for Nebuchadnezzar to come and strike Egypt (v.11) - a powerful promise of God's sovereignty
Tahpanhes was a city in Egypt where the remnant of Judah arrived (v.11) - a specific historical detail that shows God's plan for the future

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile about the consequences of rejecting God's word and choosing their own path?

This shows God's sovereignty: even in the midst of the people's rebellion, He will act (by sending Nebuchadnezzar to strike Egypt)
The stones are a sign that God's plan will be fulfilled despite the people's choice

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: The people went to Egypt because they were fleeing from the Chaldeans (Babylon) and sought refuge, but God had warned them not to go (v.3).
The stones at Pharaoh's palace are a sign that God will use Nebuchadnezzar to strike Egypt (v.11), showing that God's judgment extends beyond Judah to Egypt.
Nebuchadnezzar is the king of Babylon, and his coming to Egypt is a sign of God's sovereignty over the nations (the Babylonian Empire would be a threat to Egypt).

questions.title: Application

Think about how God's plan (the stones) will be fulfilled in the future, even when you don't see it now

tips: Thank God for the sign (the stones) that shows His sovereignty

They continue worshiping the queen of heaven (a false god) despite God's warnings
They have forgotten the evil of their ancestors and the sins of the kings of Judah

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the women's defiant declaration (v.12), the phrase 'queen of heaven' (v.13), or the consequence of their actions (v.14).

The term 'queen of heaven' is a specific idolatrous practice that was common in the surrounding cultures
The consequence: 'I will take the remnant of Judah who came to Egypt, and they shall all be consumed in Egypt' shows the finality of God's judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to the remnant of Judah who had fled to Egypt through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah warns that continuing in idolatry (especially the queen of heaven) will lead to destruction in Egypt
This passage shows that even the remnant of Judah who fled to Egypt cannot escape God's judgment for their persistent sin
The main point is that God's wrath is poured out on those who turn to false gods and forget their covenant with Him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'queen of heaven', why they went to Egypt, and the consequence of their actions.
tips: 'Queen of heaven' refers to a Canaanite goddess, but in this context, it's the idolatry of the remnant of Judah who had fled to Egypt (a practice that was common in the surrounding cultures)
The remnant of Judah who went to Egypt were those who fled the destruction of Jerusalem (v.1-2) - they were the last of Judah who had not been taken into exile by the Babylonians
The phrase 'they have forgotten the evil of their fathers' means they have not learned from the historical consequences of their ancestors' idolatry

tips: Thank God for His judgment on those who turn to idolatry
Pray for the remnant of Judah who are in Egypt to be delivered from the consequences of their sin
Ask God to help you not to follow the path of the queen of heaven in your life

This shows that God's sovereignty extends to the destruction of the land and the preservation of the faithful
The promise of preservation is a testimony to the coming exile

questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'prize of war', why God is destroying the land, or the meaning of 'seek great things'?

The destruction of the land is a direct result of Judah's unfaithfulness and the coming exile
'Seek great things for yourself' means avoiding the temptation to hope for security in the face of disaster

tips: Thank God for using His judgment to break the power of Egypt and protect His people
Pray for courage to face the 'day of the Lord' without fear, knowing God is with us
Ask God to help us trust His discipline in our lives as we face challenges
