questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the LORD is doing, WHAT He is doing, WHERE it is happening, and WHY the Philistines are being destroyed.
tips: Include the waters rising from the north as a sign of judgment (v.1-2)
Note the destruction of Gaza and Ashkelon (v.8)
The Philistines are being destroyed because they are a threat to Judah and God's plan for His people

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the destruction of Gaza (v.8), the self-mutilation of the Philistines (v.10), or the LORD's sword (v.14).
tips: The phrase 'baldness has come upon Gaza' (v.8) symbolizes the stripping of the Philistines, a sign of complete destruction
The question 'how long will you gash yourselves?' (v.10) shows the Philistines' futile attempts to escape judgment
The LORD's sword cannot rest until the work is done (v.14) is a powerful reminder of God's active judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: This passage is a warning to Judah that God's judgment is coming against the Philistines to protect Judah from their enemies
The destruction of the Philistines is part of God's plan to restore peace to Judah
The LORD's sword is active and will not rest until the work is complete (v.14)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 'waters' imagery, the meaning of 'baldness', or the self-mutilation of the Philistines.
tips: The 'waters' are a metaphor for the coming judgment, not literal water (like a flood) but the force of God's wrath
Baldness was a sign of mourning in ancient cultures, but here it indicates complete destruction of the Philistines
Gashing oneself was a ritual of mourning in ancient Near East, but the Philistines are doing it as a sign of hopelessness

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: The LORD's judgment on the Philistines shows that God's work cannot be stopped. What situation requires you to trust God's judgment this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are 'gashing yourself' (self-mutilation) in despair and trust God's judgment instead
Pray that God will use His judgment on your enemies to bring peace to your life
Practice patience and trust in God's timing, as the LORD's sword will not rest until the work is done

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment on the Philistines and ask for the rest that comes with His work.
tips: Thank God for His judgment on the enemies of His people
Pray for courage to face the coming judgment in your life
Ask God to help you stop self-mutilation and trust His provision

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 48:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between destruction and future restoration.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Moab' and the specific locations (Luhith and Horonaim) in verses 7-8
Pay attention to the phrase 'trusted in your works and treasures' (verse 9)
Note the contrast between 'strong staff broken' (verse 12) and 'restoration in the latter days' (verse 14)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who is being judged, what God commands, where the judgment occurs, and why Moab is destroyed.
tips: Include the three key points: Moab's trust in works and treasures (verse 9)
Note the specific places: Luhith (ascent) and Horonaim (descent) where weeping and destruction are heard (verse 7)
Mention the future restoration in the latter days (verse 14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Moab's self-sufficiency (verse 11), the broken strength (verse 12), or the future restoration (verse 14)?
tips: The phrase 'settled on his dregs' (verse 11) shows Moab's unchanging self-reliance and refusal to be emptied by God
'How is the strong staff broken' (verse 12) powerfully illustrates the destruction of Moab's leadership and strength
The promise of restoration in the latter days (verse 14) offers hope that even in destruction, God will bring renewal

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage about Moab?
tips: Judah should not trust in their own works and treasures but in God
Moab's destruction is a warning that self-reliance leads to judgment
The future restoration of Moab (verse 14) shows that God's covenant promises endure even in judgment

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'settled on his dregs', the curse in verse 10, or the metaphor of the broken staff?
tips: 'Settled on his dregs' (verse 11) means Moab was stuck in a low, unrefined state without being emptied by God's judgment or going into exile
The curse in verse 10 applies to anyone who is not diligent in serving God (not following through on their covenant responsibilities)
The 'strong staff broken' (verse 12) is a metaphor for the destruction of Moab's leadership and the breaking of their national strength

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This passage warns against trusting in works and treasures. What area of your life has been a 'treasure' that you've been relying on, and how can you step away from it to trust God?
tips: Identify one area where you've been relying on your own efforts (works) or material possessions
Ask God to help you see your true treasure (Christ) and not in things that will be destroyed
Pray for the courage to let go of self-reliance and trust God's provision

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the lesson of Moab: that we don't trust in our own works but in God. Also, pray for the future restoration that God promises.
tips: Thank God that He is the true treasure and not our works
Pray for the strength to trust God in difficult circumstances
Ask God to bring restoration to those who have been destroyed by their self-reliance

chapters.chapterTitle: Judgment on Ammon, Edom, and Others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 49:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between judgment and restoration in verses 1-3 and 10-12.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I will' in the promises of restoration (v.10, 12)
Listen for the emotional tone of God's judgment on Ammon and Edom (v.2-5)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God judges, WHAT He does, WHERE this judgment occurs (in the nations), and WHY He does it (to uphold His covenant with Judah).
tips: Ammon is judged for its false gods (Milcom) and loss of sons
Edom is stripped of its resources and children
Damascus, Kedar, Hazor, and Elam are also under judgment but with promises of restoration in the latter days

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the judgment on Ammon (v.1-3), the stripping of Edom (v.4-5), or the restoration of Elam (v.10-12)?
tips: The phrase 'I have stripped Esau bare' (v.4) shows complete destruction of Edom's resources and people
The promise of restoration for Elam in the 'latter days' (v.12) offers hope beyond current judgment
The contrast between judgment and restoration in the same chapter highlights God's faithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile about the nations surrounding them?
tips: God is judging the nations that have oppressed Judah (like Ammon and Edom) to protect His covenant people
The restoration promises (especially for Elam) show that God's plan includes all nations in the future
This serves as a warning to Judah that they must not rely on their enemies but on God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The judgment on Ammon, the meaning of 'stripped bare', and the promise of restoration for nations that are currently under judgment?
tips: Milcom was the god of Ammon; the phrase 'has Israel no sons?' implies that Ammon's god was causing Israel to lose its sons (a metaphor for the nation's future)
'Stripped bare' means Edom's resources and people are gone, but the promise of restoration in the latter days (after the exile) is for the nation to be renewed
The term 'latter days' refers to the time of the Messiah, as seen in the New Testament

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of restoration in the 'latter days' to your life this week?
tips: Pray for the nations that are currently being judged (like Ammon and Edom) to find hope in God's future restoration
Remember that God's judgment is not final; He promises restoration for all nations in the end
Practice trusting God's provision for your own future restoration, just as He promises for Elam

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment on the nations that have been hostile and ask for His restoration of the nations in the latter days.
tips: Thank God for the judgment on Ammon and Edom, who have been enemies of Judah
Pray for the restoration of Elam and the other nations in the future
Ask God to help you trust His promises of restoration even in the midst of current trials

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 50:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of judgment and the repeated phrases: 'Babylon is taken', 'Bel is put to shame', 'Merodach is dismayed'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'shamed' and 'dismayed' for Babylon's idols
The phrase 'for out of the north' sets the stage for the coming judgment
The shift from judgment to hope in the next verses (v.10-11) is a key emotional pivot

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (God) does WHAT (declares judgment on Babylon and calls Israel/Judah to seek God), WHERE (Babylon and the land of the Chaldeans), and WHY (because Babylon has exulted and plundered God's heritage).
tips: Include the threefold judgment: Babylon is taken, Bel is shamed, Merodach is dismayed
Note the weeping of Israel and Judah as they seek the LORD
Mention the nations from the north (Chaldeans) as the ones who will attack Babylon

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the declaration that Babylon is taken (v.1-2), the weeping of Israel and Judah seeking Zion (v.10), or the punishment of the king of Babylon as the king of Assyria (v.18)?
tips: The phrase 'My people have been lost sheep' (v.10) is deeply relatable for God's scattered church
The contrast between Babylon's pride and the humility of God's people seeking Zion
The connection to Christ as the Good Shepherd who gathers the lost sheep

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah warns Judah that Babylon will be judged and destroyed, but also calls them to return to God in the midst of their suffering
This passage shows that God's judgment on Babylon is part of His plan to bring Judah back to Zion
The connection to Christ: the Good Shepherd who gathers the lost sheep from Babylon

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of Babylon being punished as Assyria was, the identity of the 'nations from the north', and the weeping of Israel/Judah before exile?
tips: The phrase 'the people of Israel and the people of Judah shall come together' refers to the scattering of the tribes and their eventual return to Jerusalem
Babylon is the current enemy (Chaldeans) and Assyria was the previous enemy - God's pattern of judgment
The 'lost sheep' metaphor describes the scattered tribes of Israel led astray by false shepherds (enemies)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: In light of Jeremiah 50:10 ('My people have been lost sheep'), what step can you take this week to 'flee from the midst of Babylon' and seek God?
tips: Identify one area where you are 'in Babylon' (worldly pursuits, sin, or spiritual blindness)
Pray for the courage to 'seek the way to Zion' (God's presence) in your daily life
Spend time in Scripture to 'ask the way to Zion' as the passage suggests

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about God's judgment on Babylon and the need for His people to return to Him.
tips: Thank God that He judges the enemy (Babylon) and provides salvation for His people
Pray for courage to flee from the world's sin and seek God
Ask God to help you become one of His 'lost sheep' gathered by Christ

tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

Capture the main flow

Listen to your partner

Look for the big idea

Share honestly

Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Jeremiah 52:1-11 aloud, focusing on the sequence of destruction and the release of Jehoiachin.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the city' (Jeremiah 52:1, 5, 9) to emphasize the completeness of the destruction
Pay attention to the emotional weight of Zedekiah's capture and the slaughter of his sons (v. 8-10)
The phrase 'the LORD has cast them out from His presence' (v. 1) sets the tone of divine judgment

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Babylonians, Judah), WHAT (the fall of Jerusalem and destruction), WHERE (Jerusalem), WHY (rebellion against Babylon and the sin of Judah), and HOW (the sequence of events from siege to exile).
tips: Include the 11-year reign of Zedekiah and the rebellion against Babylon
Note that Nebuzaradan burned the Temple and the king's house
The release of Jehoiachin in the 37th year of exile (v. 13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the destruction of the Temple (v. 5-6), the capture of Zedekiah (v. 8-10), or the release of Jehoiachin (v. 12-13).
tips: The Temple destruction (v. 5) is the most significant event in Jewish history, symbolizing the end of the old covenant
Zedekiah's sons being slaughtered before his eyes (v. 9) shows the brutal reality of judgment
The release of Jehoiachin (v. 13) provides a glimmer of hope in the midst of destruction

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to Judah before exile through this passage?
tips: This chapter serves as a historical account of the consequences of unrepentant sin, but also points to the future hope in the Davidic line (Jehoiachin)
Jeremiah's purpose is to show that God's judgment is complete but His promises of restoration remain
The destruction of the Temple (v. 5) is a sign of the end of the old order, but the Davidic line (Jehoiachin) survives

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The destruction of the Temple, the role of Nebuzaradan, or the release of Jehoiachin?
tips: The term 'the LORD has cast them out from His presence' (v. 1) refers to the complete severance of the covenant with Judah, not just physical exile
Nebuzaradan was a Babylonian officer, not a king, so his actions were carried out under Babylonian authority
The release of Jehoiachin in the 37th year of exile (v. 13) is a sign of God's faithfulness to His covenant promises

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does this passage challenge us to respond to God's judgment in our lives?
tips: When we face the consequences of our sin (like the destruction of the Temple), we must remember the hope of restoration that God provides
Like the poor left behind (v. 10), we should be mindful of those who are vulnerable in our communities
The release of Jehoiachin (v. 13) reminds us that God will ultimately restore His people, so we should hold out hope in the midst of trials

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of God's judgment and hope in the fall of Jerusalem.
tips: Thank God for His sovereignty in the destruction of Jerusalem and the preservation of His people
Pray for courage to face the consequences of sin without despair
Ask God to reveal how He is working in the lives of those who are in exile (like the poor left behind)
